intro: Paullinia glabra, commonly known as the Brazilian pepper tree, is a member of the Sapindaceae family and is native to South America. It is a deciduous shrub or small tree that can grow up to 10 meters tall, featuring compound leaves with three to five elliptical leaflets. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that are followed by orange-red, fleshy berries. Its botanical characteristics include a thick, corky bark and a preference for tropical and subtropical climates. It is often found in moist, well-drained soils along riverbanks and in forest understories.
